citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: Specifications detailing the information that must be exchanged during a project phase, derived from Project Information Requirements to ensure that data needs are met at each lifecycle stage.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A standardized modeling language for specifying, visualizing, and documenting elements within information models, supporting the alignment of data structures with agency requirements.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A centralized digital environment used to store and manage project information throughout its lifecycle, promoting consistent data access for project stakeholders.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: The ability to exchange and use data across different platforms and software systems, ensuring seamless project information transfer.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: Specifications detailing the information needed for asset management activities, enabling efficient operational and maintenance management.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A project collaboration and information management software used within BIM projects to facilitate document and data sharing.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: The process of developing BIM models through various stages, integrating elements, detecting clashes, and validating accuracy for project milestones.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A digital tool used to manage, store, and organize project documents, often integrated with BIM for efficient information retrieval.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A comprehensive 3D model incorporating various project elements and phases to support design, construction, and management tasks.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A secure digital environment where BIM project data is organized, stored, and accessed, often used for collaboration and version control.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A database that organizes data into objects rather than tables, used in BIM to store asset data and facilitate 3D model integration.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A digital replica of physical assets, processes, and systems, used in infrastructure to enhance decision-making and optimize asset management.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: Isolated sets of information within different systems or departments, which BIM aims to integrate by promoting data interoperability and shared access.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: High-level information needs of an organization that guide project-level requirements for data modeling and exchange in BIM projects.

citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A standard for packaging, managing, and exchanging asset information in a structured format to ensure consistency in BIM projects.

citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A structured framework of documents that outline standard management procedures and roles for implementing BIM on projects.

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A Dutch standard for managing digital communication flows in infrastructure projects, used to track and validate data exchanges.

citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A final model created at the end of construction that reflects any design changes made during construction, used for asset management.

citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

citation.author: Jag Mallela, April Blackburn, Roger Grant, Michael Kennerly, Katherine Petros, Connie Yew
citation.title: Building Information Modeling (BIM) Practices in Highway Infrastructure: FHWA Global Benchmarking Program Report

definition: A structured approach to understand and design systems for human augmentation.
usage: Used to outline the principles and structure necessary for enhancing human intellectual capabilities through tools and methodologies.

citation.author: Douglas Engelbart
citation.title: Augmenting Human Intellect: A Conceptual Framework

definition: An evolving digital structure that represents interconnected lists, data points, and design adjustments, capturing the development of complex projects.
usage: Engelbart describes the architect's iterative process of adding, modifying, and viewing interconnected data, forming a digital framework representing the entire project.

citation.author: Douglas Engelbart
citation.title: Augmenting Human Intellect: A Conceptual Framework

definition: The cumulative representation of a designer’s ongoing adjustments, decisions, and considerations, mapped out within a digital framework.
usage: This 'thought structure' reflects the layered complexity of project details, recorded for reference or modification by future users.

citation.author: Douglas Engelbart
citation.title: Augmenting Human Intellect: A Conceptual Framework

definition: A process that allows the architect to analyze user flows and design functionality within the digital environment, supported by the computer 'clerk.'
usage: Engelbart’s 'clerk' supports the architect in assessing spatial arrangements, user pathways, and functional efficiency, enabling adjustments as project needs evolve.

citation.author: Douglas Engelbart
citation.title: Augmenting Human Intellect: A Conceptual Framework

definition: A model describing the 'Human using Language, Artifacts, and Methodology in which he is Trained,' representing a system where human intellectual tasks are supported by structured tools and processes to enhance problem-solving capabilities.
usage: Engelbart's H-LAM/T model emphasizes the augmentation of human intellect through coordinated tools and methodologies, facilitating complex, multi-step processes across roles.

citation.author: Douglas Engelbart
citation.title: Augmenting Human Intellect: A Conceptual Framework
